title: What makes a video go viral?
intro: Rob is keen to share funny videos - he loves cat ones. Neil is not interested. What makes people want to share them? Listen to the programme.
this_week_question: Which was one of the first videos to go viral on the internet? Was it…
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: a picture or video with an amusing caption that a lot of people share with each other online
viral when something (e.g. a video or picture) gets passed on very quickly from person to person on the internet
people the same age as ourselves who share the same social position in a group
to excite a particular feeling in somebody
to make someone excited and enthusiastic about something

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. I'm Neil. Welcome to 6 Minute English, where we like to share…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Jokes, funny stories and cat videos…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No, Rob – we like to share six useful items of vocabulary.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, that too. But first, check out this meme on my phone, Neil – Grumpy Cat – it's so cute! Shall I send it to you?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No, please don't! A meme is a picture or video with an amusing caption that a lot of people share with each other online. Well, in this programme we're talking about why some online content goes viral…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: … and some doesn't. This cat is cute because it looks so grumpy – and that means 'bad tempered'.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: An image, video, or other piece of information goes viral when it gets passed on very quickly from person to person on the internet.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So first let's start with our quiz question, Neil. Can you tell me which was one of the first videos to go viral on the internet? Was it… a) Charlie bit my finger, b) Sneezing Panda or c) Dancing Baby?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I'm going to guess 'Sneezing Panda' – because I haven't seen any of those videos.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That's ridiculous Neil. Have you been living under a rock?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Look, I just don't find silly videos particularly cute – or funny.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, OK, no need to get grumpy about it. Let's move on. Why do so many people – Neil excluded – enjoy sharing content online? Let's listen to Dr Jonah Berger, Marketing Professor at the University of Pennsylvania and author of Contagious: Why things catch on , talking about what motivates us to share.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Jonah Berger, Marketing Professor at the University of Pennsylvania and author Humans are social animals. Sharing allows us (to) feel connected to others. We share emotions, which allow us to deepen the bonds we have with our peers and with our friends.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So it's all about being connected and deepening the bonds between ourselves and our peers. Our peers are people the same age as ourselves who share the same social position in a group.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And we particularly like to share content that makes us feel emotional. Let's hear more from Dr Jonah Berger about this.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Jonah Berger, Marketing Professor at the University of Pennsylvania and author High arousal emotions include things like anger and anxiety, but also excitement and humour, low arousal – sadness and contentment. [It] turns out that those high-arousal emotions – those emotions that fire us up and cause us to take action – also drive us to share.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Arousal means 'to excite a particular feeling in somebody'. And emotions like anger and anxiety tend to cause stronger feelings than sadness and contentment.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Right – high-arousal emotions fire us up – and to fire someone up means 'to make someone excited and enthusiastic about something'. So when a video we see on the internet makes us laugh – or makes us excited or angry – then we are more likely to share it with others.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And sharing that emotion with others strengthens the connection or bond between us. That's what Dr Berger's theory says anyway.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I'm surprised that sad things aren't passed on as much as, say, funny things.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, how often do you share sad videos with your peers?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Good point. I do tend to share content that makes me laugh – more than sad or angry stuff anyway. Like the Grumpy Cat meme. Can I show it to you now?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. I'll just show you the caption. It says, "I purred once. It was terrible".

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yeah. Right. Hilarious, Rob. Now, can we have the answer to today's quiz question, please, if you've finished amusing yourself?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. OK. Which was one of the first videos to go viral on the internet?  Was it… a) Charlie Bit my Finger, b) Sneezing Panda or c) Dancing Baby?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said 'Sneezing Panda'.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, it was actually Dancing Baby. This 3-dimensional animation of a baby dancing the cha-cha was one of the first viral videos released in the late 1990s. Another popular one was the Hamster Dance by Hampton the Hamster, which appeared in 1997.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, fascinating as all that sounds, shall we look back at the words we learned today, Rob? Rob Sure. The first item was 'meme' – a picture or video with an amusing caption that a lot of people share with each other online. For example, "I tried to show Neil a hilarious meme about a grumpy cat."

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The word 'meme' was actually invented by evolutionary biologist Professor Richard Dawkins to represent an idea or concept that spreads in human culture in a similar way to a gene.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Fascinating. That sounds way too complicated, Neil. Let's move on to item number two – 'grumpy' – I gave one example just now. But here's another one: "He's the grumpiest man I've ever met."

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I hope you're not talking about me, Rob. Number three – 'to go viral' – means 'an image, video, or other piece of information that gets passed on very quickly from person to person on the Internet'. For example, "What makes a video go viral?"

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I don't know, Neil – If I knew how to make a viral video, I'd be a rich man by now!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Before computers and the internet we only talked about viral infections, didn't we? "I've got a nasty viral infection so I'm not coming into work today."

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yeah, that's right. The connection is that both viral infections and viral memes spread quickly!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK – number four. 'Peers' are people the same age as our selves who share the same social position in a group.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: For example, "Teenagers often worry about looking silly in front of their peers." Next up – arousal – that means 'to excite a particular feeling in somebody'.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: We heard about high and low-arousal emotions. The verb is 'to arouse'. For example, "The debate aroused strong feelings on both sides."

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, finally – 'to fire someone up' means 'to make someone excited and enthusiastic about something'. "I'm really fired up about today's vocabulary!"

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Good to know, Rob. But it's time to go now, but please check out our Instagram, Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Bye-bye!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Shall we watch that 'dancing baby' now, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No.
